steps.name: match response[0].project[0].technology == '#[3]'
comments: #Below code is used to validate the size of an array

steps.name: match response[0].project[*].technology[*] == ["Kotlin","SQL Lite","Gradle"]
comments: #using wildcard(*) we can validate exact response by using == operator or can use contains to validate any one item in response
#Note the order will remain the same as that of the response received otherwise our assertion will fail

elements.name: To get the response in JSON format and do assertions via fuzzy matchers

[{"jobId":1,"jobTitle":"Software Engg","jobDescription":"To develop andriod application","experience":["Google","Apple","Mobile Iron"],"project":[{"projectName":"Movie App","technology":["Kotlin","SQL Lite","Gradle"]}]},{"jobId":49,"jobTitle":"Bachelor in commerce","jobDescription":"To do accounting","experience":["Google","Apple","Sai krupa computer academy"],"project":[{"projectName":"Accounts for car dekho","technology":["Tally","PGDCA"]}]}]

steps.name: match each response[0].project[0].technology == '#string'
comments: #each keyword validates each element of an array is string or not

steps.name: match response[0].project[0].technology == '#?_.includes("Kotlin")'
comments: #'#[]' -> used to validate if that json object is an array or not

steps.name: match response[0].jobId == '#number?_ >= 0'
comments: #below expression validates that jobID obj is a number greater than equal to zero

steps.name: match response[0].project[0].technology == '#[3] #string?_.length >=2'
comments: #below expression validates that technology obj is an array of size 3,every element inside it is a string and every string length is greater than 2

steps.name: match response[0].jobDescription == '#regex [A-Za-z\\s]+'
comments: #Below expression uses regular expression to match the characters present in jobDescription field

name: com/api/automation/getRequest/Validations.feature
description: Validations to be performed on response received
